abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory, and sustainability is unlikely. The key
            lessons suggest that even though, adaptive research is an
            essential, and continuous need for small farmers'
            competitiveness, it may turn against them, as in this case,
            because the environment where small farmers operate, is also
            that where large-scale, entrepreneurial, and most
            importantly, export-oriented larger farmers, and
            agro-industries operate, de-facto, a barrier to small
            farmers' success. Furthermore, while creditworthiness,
            and technology transfer are necessary to increase
            productivity, these alone, are not sufficient to guarantee
            income increases; instead, the sum of other factors, such as
            infrastructure, marketing, and farmer organizations
            development, could prod an open environment competitiveness
            in farming development. Attempting to improve the
            livelihoods of small -particularly poor - farmers, project
            design failed to include a detailed, and realistic social
            assessment, which could have ensured financial
            sustainability, while protecting cost, and credit recovery.
            In addition, this operation supported an ongoing government
            program, bearing the risks of restructuring, and government
            policy changes, whereas consideration of options, such as
            project reformulation or restructuring, even loan
            cancellation should have been evaluated.
